node.plaintext:
Mom: "Yes, it was actually me!"
Me: "I know. I saw the code."
Me: "Quote: We are not quite sure what it's doing, but it's called daily and
runs since 1985 without a change."

â€” Rem0te (@grauhut) May 28, 2018
[https://twitter.com/grauhut/status/1001020570664886273?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw]
https://towardsdatascience.com/embedding-machine-learning-models-to-web-apps-part-1-6ab7b55ee428

https://www.manning.com/books/exploring-data-with-python

https://www.citusdata.com/blog/2018/06/01/fun-with-sql-window-functions-in-postgresql/

https://lispcast.com/avoid-naming-at-all-costs/
node.html:
Mom: "Yes, it was actually me!"
Me: "I know. I saw the code."
Me: "Quote: We are not quite sure what it's doing, but it's called daily and runs since 1985 without a change."

— Rem0te (@grauhut) May 28, 2018

https://towardsdatascience.com/embedding-machine-learning-models-to-web-apps-part-1-6ab7b55ee428

https://www.manning.com/books/exploring-data-with-python

https://www.citusdata.com/blog/2018/06/01/fun-with-sql-window-functions-in-postgresql/

https://lispcast.com/avoid-naming-at-all-costs/

node.plaintext:
https://github.com/diana-hep/histbook

https://lifehacker.com/how-to-time-your-caffeine-consumption-and-maximize-aler-1826619383

There's a thingy called "Belief Change Blindness" - basically, once you've
changed your mind about something, you forget you ever thought differently.
Kinda applies to learning, too - once you learn something it can be hard to
"retrace your steps" in order to figure out how to teach it to someone else, cuz
unless you hold onto (or record) those memories, you're inclined to forget them.
https://medium.com/tensorflow/ignorance-is-my-superpower-b8155e7cc59b

https://www.datacamp.com/community/tutorials/converting-strings-datetime-objects

https://www.popsci.com/honeybees-counting-neuroscience
node.html:
https://github.com/diana-hep/histbook

https://lifehacker.com/how-to-time-your-caffeine-consumption-and-maximize-aler-1826619383

There's a thingy called "Belief Change Blindness" - basically, once you've changed your mind about something, you forget you ever thought differently. Kinda applies to learning, too - once you learn something it can be hard to "retrace your steps" in order to figure out how to teach it to someone else, cuz unless you hold onto (or record) those memories, you're inclined to forget them.
https://medium.com/tensorflow/ignorance-is-my-superpower-b8155e7cc59b

https://www.datacamp.com/community/tutorials/converting-strings-datetime-objects

https://www.popsci.com/honeybees-counting-neuroscience
